_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Dallas Water Utilities
Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant
Risk Management Program  
Executive Summary

1.0  Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies
The Dallas Water Utilities Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant is committed to the safety of our workers, the public, and the environment. The resources invested in the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances demonstrate this commitment. The Dallas Water Utilities Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant implements reasonable controls, such as training of personnel and the safe design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes. Our policy is to make every effort to prevent the release of hazardous substances but in the event of a release, our trained personnel will coordinate with local emergency response agencies and first responders to control and contain the release in a manner that will be safe for workers and will help prevent injuries to the public or the environment.

2.0 Description of The Dallas Water Utilities Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant and Regulated Substances
The Dallas Water Utilities Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant handles two substances regulated by the Risk Management Plan Rule (RMP Rule) in quantities above the Threshold Quantity. These substances are:

Regulated Substances: 	Chlorine: Stored in 90-ton rail cars and bulk storage tanks.
			Anhydrous Ammonia: Stored in bulk storage tanks.
	
Process Description: Part of the treatment process at the Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant includes the use of chlorine and anhydrous ammonia to form chloramines. When compared to chlorine disinfection, chloramination can provide better protection against certain bacterial regrowth due to greater residual stability than free chlorine alone. 

3.0  Hazard Assessment - Toxic Substances
In order to aid the RMP Team in accident prevention planning, we have conducted a conservative analysis of accidental release scenarios including modeling, population surveys and environmental assessment of poten

tial consequences. 
The worst-case scenarios (WCS) associated with Regulated Toxic Substances is a failure of a full storage tank of chlorine and anhydrous ammonia.  An alternative release scenario (ARS) for chlorine and anhydrous ammonia were a release from a transfer hose failure.  By evaluating and modeling the potential consequences of these scenarios, we are better able to focus our efforts regarding emergency prevention and response specific to each chemicals hazard.

4.0 Accidental Release Prevention Program
The Dallas Water Utilities Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant performed an offsite consequence analysis to estimate the potential impacts of accidental releases of the chlorine and anhydrous ammonia from our process. The regulated substance was evaluated for a possible worse-case release scenario and alternative release scenario. It is important to understand that the Dallas Water Utilities Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant has invested extensive resources to prevent releases, and the potential for a worse-case release is extremely small. The alternative release scenario represents a more realistic potential for occurrence and is based on historical data from our process or other similar processes. By identifying these potential releases, the Dallas Water Utilities Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant has developed an extensive program to prevent such an occurrence. This program is discussed in detail in the Prevention Program section of this plan.

The primary objective of performing the offsite consequence analysis is to determine the distance at which certain effects might occur to the public and/or the environment as a result of an accidental release.  This point is called the endpoint distance.  At distances less than the endpoint distance, the effects would be greater; at distances farther than the endpoint, the effects would be less.

The RMP Rule requires that a prevention program be established for The Dallas Water Utilities Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant Ch

lorination and Ammoniation processes. The following details the prevention program elements at The Dallas Water Utilities Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant that apply to these processes.

4.1 Process Safety Information
The Dallas Water Utilities Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant maintains a variety of technical documents that help ensure the safe operation of our processes.  These documents address:
 physical properties of hazardous substances handled,
 chemical properties and associated hazards of those substances,
 operating parameters and limitation(s) of the process equipment,
 design basis and configuration of the equipment, and
 specific chemical inventories.

The Dallas Water Utilities Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant ensures that the process safety information is available to all Dallas Water Utilities Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant employees, the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), and the local fire department.  
Chemical specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in safety data sheets (SDSs). 
This information is supplemented by other technical information specific for these chemicals.  Continuous attention is given to revisions and updates on the hazards of anhydrous ammonia and other chemicals used in our process.  Information regarding toxicity, environmental impacts, corrosion concerns, inadvertent mixing hazards, and other safety and health concerns are addressed and communicated to the appropriate parties.

The Dallas Water Utilities Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design, construction, and operating parameters of process equipment.  This information includes:
 materials of construction,
 design pressures,
 temperature ratings,
 electrical ratings,
 flow limits,
 block flow diagrams,
 consequences of deviation from operating limits,
 safety systems,
 applicable design codes and standar

ds,
 process chemistry, and
 design basis for relief and ventilation systems.
All the above mentioned information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provide a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the Chlorination and Ammoniation Process are not compromised.

4.2 Process Hazard Review
The Dallas Water Utilities Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant performed and will periodically update process hazard review (PHRs) of the Chlorination and Ammoniation Process to help identify process hazards and generate recommendations that might improve the safe operation of the process.  Within this program, the Chlorination & Ammoniation Process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.

To perform the PHRs, Dallas Water Utilities Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant primarily uses the "What-if/Checklist" technique.  The PHRs are conducted using a team of people with experience in engineering and Chlorination/Ammoniation Process operation and a leader with experience in process hazard analysis techniques. This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and/or mitigation measures, when appropriate.  The team then prepares a written report describing the results of the analysis, including a list of recommendations ranked according to relative risk ratings assigned by the team.  

To help ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviate significantly from the original design safety features, the Dallas Water Utilities Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results.  These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the Chlorination and Ammoniation Processes are no longer in operation.  The resul

ts and findings of these updates are documented and retained.  


4.3 Operating Procedures
The Dallas Water Utilities Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant engineers, operators, and management work together to develop and maintain written operating procedures to define how tasks related to the Chlorination and Ammoniation Process operation should be safely performed.  These written procedures address various modes of process operations, such as:
 normal startup,
 normal operations,
 temporary operations,
 emergency shutdown,
 normal shutdown, and
 initial startup of a new process.

 The written operating procedures include:
 steps for safely conducting process tasks,
 applicable process safety information, such as safe operating limits and consequences of process deviations, and
 safety and health considerations, such as chemical hazards, personal protective equipment requirements, and action(s) to take in the event of an exposure to a hazardous substance.

4.4 Training
The Dallas Water Utilities Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant trains workers to safely and effectively perform their assigned tasks. This training program includes initial training which includes the components below, and is followed by hands on training with an experienced operator until proficiency has been demonstrated. Refresher training is conducted at least every three years and includes the following components:
 a general overview of the Chlorination & Ammoniation Process,
 the properties and hazards of the substances in the process, and
 a detailed review of the process operating procedures and safe work practices.
 verification of employee understanding of hazards and safe operating procedures. 

4.5  Mechanical Integrity
The Dallas Water Utilities Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant maintains the mechanical integrity of Chlorination and Ammoniation Process equipment to help prevent failures that could endanger workers, the public, or the environment.  The Dallas Water Utilities Elm Fork Water

Treatment Plant mechanical integrity program includes:
 an inspection and testing program to help identify equipment deterioration and damage before the equipment fails,
 a quality assurance program to help ensure that the new and replacement equipment meet the design standards required for service in our process,
 procedures for safe work practices such as lockout/tagout, hot work, confined space entry and line or equipment opening,
 training of maintenance personnel, and
 documentation of maintenance activities.

4.6 Compliance Audit
The Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant conducts compliance audits of the Risk Management Program at least every three years. Audits are conducted by a team of hourly and management personnel who are knowledgeable of the RMP Rule and the Chlorination and Ammoniation Processes. The team evaluates the Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant Prevention Program and other aspects of the Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant Risk Management Program. The results of the audit are documented, recommendations are resolved, appropriate enhancements to the Prevention Program are implemented, and maintains records of at least the last two audits conducted. 

4.7 Incident Investigation 
If an event occurs that results in an accident or a near miss, the Elm Fork Water Treatment Plants Incident investigation policy would be implemented;  results of this policy include documentation of investigation, resolution of issues identified, implementation of process improvements identified and discussion of results with applicable employees. 


4.8  Chemical Specific Prevention Steps
Industry standards are followed at the Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant to help ensure safe handling of chlorine and anhydrous ammonia.  The vendor supplies chlorine and anhydrous ammonia via a Department of Transportation (DOT) approved truck and in DOT approved tanks.  The Chlorination and Ammoniation Process equipment is designed and constructed with state-of-the-art materials and technology

utilizing the standards and guidelines of the Chlorine Institute, American Water Works Association, ASME, ANSI, CGA, and other applicable codes.  Workers who perform operations involving chlorine or anhydrous ammonia receive training emphasizing safe handling procedures according to the guidelines required by the Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant. 

5.0 Five Year Accident History
The Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant has had no chemical accidents within the last 5 years.

6.0  Emergency Response 
The Dallas Water Utilities Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant has prepared a written emergency response/action plan that complies with the RMP Rule, other federal standards and industry guidelines.  This plan has been communicated to the Local Emergency Planning Committee LEPC/EMA and local fire department under the coordination rules of the RMP.

7.0  Planned Changes to Improve Safety
The Dallas Water Utilities Elm Fork Water Treatment Plant continuously strives to improve the safety of our processes through incident investigation, Process Hazard Analysis, and employee suggestions.  Our engineering and technical personnel stay abreast of technology advancements which may improve the safety of our processes.
